Bradley Graham calls the book's tone "characteristically tough and defiant" as Donald Rumsfeld also criticizes Bush's shortcomings in resolving issues among senior advisers. Still, his barbs stop short of ad hominem attacks, and the memoir, even with its flashes of lingering resentment, maintains a measured tone. Wishes Bush Had Let Him Go Earlier In the book, Donald Rumsfeld explains that on two separate occasions after the story of Iraqi detainee abuse at Abu Ghraib broke out, he offered his resignation to the president. It inspired economists Salvatore Modica and Aldo Rustichini to pontificate thus: A subject is certain of something when he knows that thing; he is uncertain when he does not know it, but he knows he does not... he is unaware of something when he does not know it, and he does not know he does not know. Psychoanalytic philosopher Slavoj i?ek went one step further and defined what even Mr Donald Rumsfeld missed: the unknown known, things we don't know we know. In Washington, Donald Rumsfeld was known as a tenacious and effective fighter of policy wars, once described by Henry Kissinger as a skilled full-time politician-bureaucrat in whom ambition, ability, and substance fuse seamlessly. In the 1970s, as chief of staff and then defense secretary in the Ford administration, Donald Rumsfeld clashed with Henry Kissinger , then secretary of state, with Donald Rumsfeld opposing- and helping to prevent, by many accounts-
